 Christianity as it exists today is the bloated and distorted offshoot of a first-century faith healing cult. We know hardly anything about its eponymous figurehead: there may indeed have been an itinerant preacher and healer called Jesus of Nazareth, or the character in the books may be an amalgam of several such preachers. The earliest known writings after his alleged execution (Paul's letters) contain virtually nothing about the man's life - no nativity myth, no miracles, no teaching in parables. These were added and embellished in the gospels, thought to have been written between 70 and 110 CE by authors unknown. Everything we think we know, therefore, comes from multiple second- and third-hand sources written many decades after the alleged events.
 
 The status of christianity as a world religion today has two major root causes:
 [*]The fortuitous conversion of Constantine after his victory at Milvian Bridge in 312 CE.[*]Christianity's astonishing willingness - in contrast to, say, Judaism or Islam - to bend itself to fit the prevailing customs of societies outside its region of origin. In its Roman Catholic and Orthodox versions it became a polytheism in all but name, with patron saints occupying the role of former local gods, and the BVM providing a mother-goddess substitute. If Jesus of Nazareth existed, it is unlikely that he would recognise the teachings and practices of modern-day christian churches as having anything to do with him.
